title: Modeling Tabular Postcards with Slope Field

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “P of t, in number of postcards remaining.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. P of t is negative 10. Column 2. t is 8. P of t is negative 8. Column 3. t is 24. P of t is negative 5. Column 4. t is 35. P of t is negative 4." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>35</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(number of postcards remaining per minute)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student is delivering postcards to teachers from students on a school trip. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate at which the total number of postcards remaining to deliver is changing, in number of postcards remaining per minute, is modeled by an increasing, twice-differentiable function <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="P of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a left Riemann sum with the three subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 35, of, P of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the calculations that lead to your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “P of t, in number of postcards remaining.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. P of t is negative 10. Column 2. t is 8. P of t is negative 8. Column 3. t is 24. P of t is negative 5. Column 4. t is 35. P of t is negative 4." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>35</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(number of postcards remaining per minute)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student is delivering postcards to teachers from students on a school trip. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate at which the total number of postcards remaining to deliver is changing, in number of postcards remaining per minute, is modeled by an increasing, twice-differentiable function <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="P of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a left Riemann sum with the three subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 35, of, P of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the calculations that lead to your answer.

(b) Is your answer from part (a) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 35, of, P of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="P prime of 24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="8 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Explain the meaning of <math alttext="P prime of 24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(e) It is known that <math alttext="P prime of 8, equals 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals P of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 24, of, P prime of the fraction t over 3, end fraction, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the calculations that lead to your answer.

(g) Another student brings a bag full of postcards to deliver as well. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of postcards delivered to teachers by this student can be modeled by the increasing, differentiable function <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume the weight of each postcard is <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> grams. Write an expression for the rate of change, in grams per minute, of the total weight of postcards delivered by the second student at <math alttext="t equals 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

(h) Explain why the following could not be a slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals R prime of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for the function <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined in part (g).

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
